headline: Lamb, Fetterman, And Kenyatta Walk Into A Bar. It Is Full Of Commenters Bitching About 2016.
author: Stephen Robinson
sentences:
On Twitter, Brownworth called the Politico article an “incredibly disappointing piece that reduces Malcolm Kenyatta's run to a paragraph and mentions Black voters — still the Democratic base and the majority of Philly voters — twice.”
Kenyatta has more endorsements than any of the top three candidates and ranks side by side with Fetterman in polling.

The mighty Democratic establishment is apparently so spooked by progressives that Pennsylvania Democrats have declined to endorse anyone, a perceived blow to Lamb, and the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee is also taking the bold position of “our name’s Paul, and this is between y’all."

Journalist Victoria A. Brownworth reports that Kenyatta boasts "a massive number of pivotal endorsements among progressive groups and labor unions” and would "make history as the first openly gay man and first LGBTQ person of color elected to the US Senate.

In addition to his numerous TV appearances, there were Twitter exchanges like this one:
Lamb supporters have argued that the 2013 incident when Fetterrman pulled a shotgun on a Black guy could make it hard to rally Black voters to the polls in November.

As New York congressional candidate Maya Contreras observed on a recent Wonkette live chat: Any politician who holds political office is a member of the “establishment.” This is a somewhat meaningless distinction.

I end this post with the obligatory comment that all three candidates are superior to whomever Republicans end up nominating, and the obligatory reminder to STOP FIGHTING IN THE COMMENTS, JEEZ YOU GUYS.
And yet we still, a century later, go back to Hillary vs. Bernie, as Fetterman was a Sanders supporter (he wasn't rude about it), and some people will go to their graves being tiresome about it.
Kenyatta has accused Fetterman of avoiding the Black vote after the lieutenant governor skipped an event with 25 Black clergy members (he was presiding over the opening of the Senate session).
Also, Christopher Miyares, the guy on the other end of Fetterman’s shotgun, claims Fetterman “lied about everything” but still hopes he “gets to be senator.” He’s welcome to that opinion.
A former Marine and prosecutor, Lamb catapulted onto the national scene in 2018 when he flipped a House seat that former President Donald Trump carried by nearly 20 points.
Lamb has argued that he’s the "most electable candidate,” but Democratic voters have reason to worry about electing any more self-obsessed glory hounds like Kyrsten Sinema.
However, Nina Turner wasn't without establishment support (and a significant amount of money) when Shontel Brown defeated her in the Ohio 11 congressional race.
Democratic strategist James Carville’s super PAC is helping Lamb, who was eight years old when Carville’s big hit, “It’s The Economy Stupid,” topped the charts.
He’s the current chair of the powerful Senate Budget Committee, so he’s no less a part of the establishment than House Majority Whip Jim Clyburn.
Dismissing the actual left candidate — Kenyatta — or Fetterman while ignoring Fetterman's and Lamb's problems with Black voters is lax at best.
Pennsylvania Democrats don’t have a binary choice between what Politico describes as the “progressive” Fetterman and the “centrist” Lamb.
Holly Otterbein at Politico has already written an elegy for Rep. Conor Lamb, who’s remarkably lively for an apparent political corpse.
For now, Lamb is downplaying current polls and looking forward, even though some of his Democratic backers represent the distant past.
However, most active Black Pennsylvania voters are already participating in the Democratic primary, which Fetterman is leading.
Fetterman rose to wider prominence in 2020 when he defended the state against Donald Trump’s Big Lies about election fraud.
A big Democratic pitch for 2022 is not just keeping the Senate majority but electing at least two more reliable Democrats.
Lamb has twice voted against Nancy Pelosi for House speaker, but he’s at least come out in favor of nuking the filibuster.
Former Pennsylvania Governor Ed Rendell is also in Lamb’s corner, which usually means you should change corners.
Yes, it’s certainly helpful when a candidate has the support of Democratic leadership and their own colleagues.
Conor Lamb is the kind of swing-state Senate candidate who used to make Democratic power-brokers swoon.
Otterbein frames this as yet another battle between the “Left” and the Democratic establishment.
Despite Lamb’s obvious eHarmony appeal, Pennsylvania Democrats aren’t swooning at the polls.
President Joe Biden said the young, centrist lawmaker reminds him of his late son, Beau.
Yr Wonkette is 100 percent ad-free and entirely supported by reader donations.
He would also be the youngest member of the Senate.” (Sorry, Jon Ossoff.)
Senator Bernie Sanders endorsed and campaigned for Turner.
That already makes him better than Sinema and Joe Manchin.
Philadelphia state Rep. Malcolm Kenyatta is also running.
Meanwhile, Fetterman's direct quote — "PUT ME IN COACH!"
I’ve yet to endorse anyone who’s pulled a gun on me.
John Fetterman in both fundraising and the polls.
Please click the clickie, if you are able.
Maybe the power brokers are out of touch?
— promised a Biden vote for every pot.
Kenyatta and Lamb both participated.
(No, it’s the voters who are wrong!)
How often would you like to donate?
(And yes, you know who you are.)
Lamb is trailing Lt. Gov.
No really, we mean it.
That's you!
